CHRONSTRUCT.BIRTHPOSITION: Frances Henrietta Müller, who later called herself Henrietta Müller, was born in Valparaiso, Chile, one of a family of at least four.

SHORTPROSE.P: HM spent her early years living at her family estate in Las Zorras, Chile, where her father was a wealthy German émigré. 161 (28 November 1891): 915 under Eva Maria McLaren After her family settled in England she involved herself thoroughly in national life (as did her parents); they became a de facto English family. HM remained unmarried by choice and preference. ODNB
HM's privileged upbringing allowed her family to travel widely before her family eventually decided to live in England.

The Müller family, originally based at Las Zorras, an estate in Chile, settled after their extensive travels in England, at an estate named Hillside at Shenley in Hertfordshire. They also established a town house at 86 Porland Place
London

Henrietta's father, William Müller, was born and raised at Bremen in Germany, the son of a professional, a Mr J. W. Müller. He was a successful businessman. After his family settled in
Hertfordshire, he became a justice of the peace. He died on 18 August 1881 at the age of seventy. 11031 (24 August 1881):

Henrietta's mother, Maria Henrietta Müller, was of English descent, though she appears to have been born, like her children, in Chile. Mrs. Müller was committed, along with both her daughters, to the cause of feminism. In 1880 she joined the Central Committee of the National Society for Women's Suffrage, and from then onwards became increasingly involved with feminist agitation, giving her support to the Society for Promoting the Employment of Women, the Ladies National Association for the Repeal of the Contagious Diseases Acts and the Central National Society for Women's Suffrage, among others. Henrietta accorded a great deal of respect to her mother, who, she said, sympathises with me very greatly in my efforts and has always done what she could to encourage a spirit of freedom and independence in her daughters; she is a woman of remarkable originality of character

Henrietta Müller had at least two sisters and one brother. She was closest to her youngest sister, Eva Maria, later McLaren, who campaigned with HM as a social reformer and activist. Together, Eva and Henrietta mountaineered in the Swiss Alps, involved themselves with organized philanthropy, and participated in the organization of The Women's Penny Paper. Eva Maria married Walter Stowe Bright McLaren on 18 April 1883.

DIV2.HEADING: Single By Choice
DIV2.SHORTPROSE: Henrietta Müller neither married nor bore children. Instead, she embraced her identity as a single woman, cast[ing] men aside to live a life of intellectual, spiritual, and physical freedom. 66 She suggested that the maternal instinct was absent in many women, and argued that mothers stunt their own humanity in their children's service, and in revenge the children are stunted too. 29, 319>

DIV1.HEADING: Education

SHORTPROSE.P: As a child, Henrietta was privately taught in Valparaiso and London , and her education was generally not that of the school. She spoke fluent French, Spanish, German, and Italian, as well as some Greek, and Latin.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: In her late twenties, HM became one of the first batch of students to study at Girton College, Cambridge, despite some opposition from her Father

SHORTPROSE.P: This was the first year that Girton was located at the village of the same name, just outside Cambridge, instead of further away at Hitchin. While enrolled there, HM was inspired-in part by Emily Davies-to champion the cause of women. she helped to found the Women's Printing Society and aided Emma Paterson's efforts to establish trade unions among women.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE:
HM took a third in the moral science tripos at Girton College, Cambridge
A third means a third-class honours or one level above a pass degree: respectable but not particularly distinguished. In this case taking a degree means qualifying for one: women were not admitted to degrees from Cambridge until a decision by the university Senate on 6 December 1947. The tripos refers to a course of study comprising philosophy and other subjects now classed as social sciences.

SHORTPROSE.P: After her studies at Girton, Henrietta Müller established herself as an political activist devoted to the social advancement of women. Independently wealthy with no need to earn her living, she was able to pursue this cause without any material constraints.
In 1878, she took her first official foray into politics when she stood for election to the London School Board in the Lambeth division.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: HM was elected to the London School Board in a landslide, topping the poll with 19,000 votes. She was the third woman on the board; this was the month after Emily Davies and Elizabeth Garrett resigned.

SHORTPROSE.P: Her predecessors had argued that it was impossible for two women to oversee all education of girls in London (while boys had forty-seven men attending to their interests). Nevertheless HM, flying her stripes with the Liberal party, remained on the board through two more elections, which she calculated as costing her £12,000.4267 (18 October 1883): 3 She resigned her position in 1885. Throughout her career on the school board, she took a common-sense approach to educational reform, advocating in one instance (on health grounds) a reduction in the required number of stitches to the inch that girls had to sew, which had surpassed the finest work sold in London shops. She also championed the cause of adult women employed in education; she succeeded in her efforts for the employment of female clerks, and attempted to gain wage parity for male and female teachers (which was not achieved until 1961, well after her death).

DIV2.HEADING: National Vigilance Association, Personal Rights Association, and the Criminal Law Amendment Bill

SHORTPROSE.P: During and after her time with the London School Board, HM was also a member of the National Vigilance Association or NVA and the Personal Rights Association or PRA, which both campaigned against the sexual exploitation of women and girls. However, while the NVA demanded the closure of brothels, the PRA expressed concern about the double standard implicit in any closures, which would, they pointed out, cause hardship for women more than for men.111, 101-2 Henrietta Müller herself objected to the persecution of prostitutes, writing that a woman has rights as a woman, even though she be a prostitute.101-2 Still, she supported the enforcement of the Criminal Law Amendment Bill of August 1885, which outlawed brothel-keeping and prostitution, but also raised the age of consent from thirteen to sixteen for girls.8213

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: After the Criminal Law Amendment Bill passed, HM led Women's Trade Unions members and Army Clothing Establishment workers in a Hyde Park demonstration demanding enforcement of the age-of-consent clause.

SHORTPROSE.P: She resigned from the NVA in 1888. She had been on the executive and legal sub-committee, but disagreed with its characterization of birth-control pamphlets as vicious literature as well as its zeal for closing brothels.111

Henrietta Müller's public engagement with the social and political advancement of women was deeply involved and far reaching. She was committed to a host of feminist organizations, many of which she founded, and which employed her great energy and public speaking talents in the service of political reform.429 In 1880, she was a member of the Central Committee of the National Society for Women's Suffrage, and she was on its executive committee from 1889.429 In 1881 she served on the executive and management committees for the first female hall of residence at University College, London, and the London School of Medicine,151 and in 1883 she founded and became the first secretary for the Society for Promoting the Return of Women as Poor Law Guardians. Although she was engaged in extensive travel around the same time, she became the vice-president of the Women's Progressive Union in 1892.429 In addition to these commitments, she was also a member of the Moral Reform Union.430

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: In a letter to the Pall Mall Gazette HM declared that she would not pay taxes to the government as a protest against being denied the right to vote. This action made headlines for the suffrage movement.

SHORTPROSE.P: Having become a householder (at 58 Cadogan Place in south-west London) for the first time the year before, 5932 (11 March 1884): 2 Müller refused to pay when she received her initial rates bill, and wrote to her tax collector that she was compelled by conscientious motives and by my principles, to offer this resistance to a law which I believed to be unjust and arbitrary.(12 June 1884): 11 She realized that this would eventually result in the seizure of her goods, but declared herself prepared to take the full consequences of [her] action, feeling that no indignity to which [she] may be subjected can be worse than that of the political slavery that [she] now suffer[s].(12 June 1884): 11 Her possessions were eventually taken to cover the amount due and sold at a public auction, but not without protest: on the day of the auction Müller gave a speech which the crowd resolved to send to Prime Minister Gladstone.42911926 (3 July 1884) HM's friends Mr and Mrs Thomasson kindly purchased her belongings, and they were returned to her just a few days later.161 (28 November 1891): 916 Many other women later took up this means of protest against non-representation, including writers Flora Annie Steel and Evelyn Sharp.

DIV2.HEADING: Public Support for Victim of Rape

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Henrietta Müller disobeyed an order for all women to leave the magistrate's courtroom during a rape case, to give her moral support to the victim.

SHORTPROSE.P: HM had observed that the young girl, who was made pregnant by her uncle, needed the presence of one or two of her own sex in court while she testified.253 Müller had also ensured that the man was charged with rape rather than incest, which was not at that time a criminal offence.253
News of her actions reached across the Atlantic, where the Women's Journal of Boston reported her moral courage.6939 (14 June 1887)

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Henrietta Müller joined Karl Pearson's Men and Women's Club, a London circle of freethinkers which discussed topics including prostitution, sexuality, marriage, birth control, and women's emancipation.

SHORTPROSE.P: Her participation was initially feared because Elizabeth Cobb considered her too radical: a manhater who was warped in her moral nature.13 Olive Schreiner, however, described her warmly, as a plucky, fearless, brave, true little woman.14 HM presented several papers which criticized the moral inferiority of men and championed greater freedom for women.13-14 For instance, she defended women's right to birth control in order to prevent unwelcome motherhood and to challenge the dominion of men.157-8

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: HM resigned from the Men and Women's Club in anger when she decided that women's participation was limited owing to their intimidation by men.

SHORTPROSE.P: With her resignation, Müller declared to Olive Schreiner that the club was a piteous failure.43 She promised to start a similar group exclusively for women, but founded The Women's Penny Paper instead.160n89

HM's activities as a member of the London School Board, as member and office-holder of the National Society for Women's Suffrage and other organizations, and as a campaigner for better treatment for prostitutes, did not absorb all her energy.

Henrietta Müller adopted the editorial pseudonym Helena B. Temple when she founded and launched on 27 October 1888 The Women's Penny Paper, which proudly called itself the only paper in the world conducted, written, printed and published by women. In its inaugural issue the paper outlined its progressive policy and commitment to the coverage of feminist activity, the rational dress movement, and women in India, as well as of local and international news.165 The paper began with a limit of eight pages, but soon expanded in size.429

Around 1890 or 1891 it changed its name to The Woman's Herald, though it continued to be edited by Müller until she moved to India. Her sister Eva Maria McLaren subsequently took the reins. The paper was reborn in January 1894 as the Woman's Signal and was eventually owned and edited by Florence Fenwick Miller.430

Henrietta Müller embarked on several cross-ocean voyages over her lifetime; her love of travel was in part inspired by her nomadic childhood.under HM and Eva Maria McLaren In the winter of 1886 she travelled to Egypt, where she visited Cairo, Assouan or Aswan, Philae, and Luxor, returning home via Athens and Corfu.6583 (12 April 1886): 14

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Drawn by its ideals of spiritual and sexual equality, Henrietta Müller joined the Theosophical Society and increasingly connected her feminist politics to her spiritual ideals.

SHORTPROSE.P: Following her inauguration into the Theosophical Society, HM withdrew from many strictly civic efforts, to travel to and live in India, China and America.
She resigned from the Theosophical Society, however, in 1895.175

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Henrietta Müller embarked on a Theosophist lecture tour on her own in India.

SHORTPROSE.P: She had planned to accompany Annie Besant, but at the last minute Besant cancelled and Müller went alone.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: HM, travelling this time with Annie Besant, visited Chicago to attend the Parliament of Religions, at which she addressed the Theosophical congress.

SHORTPROSE.P: The Parliament of Religions was held in connection with the Chicago World's Fair or International Exhibition. The addresses of the Theosophical congress were so popular that an extra session was held in the Great Hall of Washington, which accommodated over thirty-five hundred people. 392-3

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: HM landed for a second time on the mainland of India, where, along with Besant, she spoke before crowds of people. They had begun their lecture tour in Ceylon.

SHORTPROSE.P: Indian women gathered in large numbers to hear Müller, the renowned woman-suffragist, speak.

DIV2.HEADING: Swami Vivekananda and the Ramakrishna Movement

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: HM invited the influential Hindu thinker Swami Vivekananda to London, where he began a lecture tour.

SHORTPROSE.P: She had met Vivekananda at the Parliament of Religions in Chicago. Compelled by his argument for the centrality of social service in the traditional Indian spiritual disciplines, she soon became his disciple.under HM and Swami Vivekananda

HM travelled with Vivekananda to Switzerland some time in later 1896 on a spiritual retreat.26, 36 In 1897 she set out for Calcutta and Almora to devote her time and energy to Vivekananda's Ramakrishna Mission.169, 59-60, 68

Vivekananda intended the Ramakrishna Mission to build three monastic centres and a school for Hindu girls.169, 59-60, 68 HM eventually distanced herself from the movement, however, after coming to judge that it remained centred on phallic worship175 and was insufficiently ascetic. She then levelled strong criticisms against female disciples who worship[ed] at Swami's feet.305

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: HM initiated legal proceedings for the adoption of an adult Bengali son, Akshaya Kumar Ghose, who took her name. She hoped he would study law and then become a politician committed to reform.

SHORTPROSE.P: However, her will, made in 1897, makes no mention of any son; nor does her obituary. It is not clear whether the adoption was formalized.10.1 (April 1895): 31

In October 1896, Henrietta Müller was living at Airlie Lodge in Ridgway Gardens in Wimbledon.48, 51 She seems to have sold this house at some point after this. Throughout her travels she maintained her permanent address at the Westminster Palace Hotel in London.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Henrietta Müller died in Washington, DC.

SHORTPROSE.P: An obituary in The Times took note of her significant contribution to women's social and political advancement, saying that throughout her life her heart was in the women's movement.37919 (17 January 1906): 6
